356.description: If you have accidentally burnt milk at the bottom of the pot, it's easier to remove by washing it with granulated sugar. You won't need to scrub as much as with dish soap.

357.title: Wine Residue
357.description: Save the red wine leftover from Saturday night by freezing it into wine ice cubes. When cooking sauce and want to add a little extra, it's convenient to have small ice cubes on hand. This also works with leftover cream or after making broth. The practical format makes it easy to measure! If you have a lot of liquid, it's easiest to use plastic ice cube bags available in grocery stores.

358.title: Winter Cleaning for Rugs
358.description: An effective way to clean rugs when there's snow outside is to first cool the rug outdoors for a while, and then place it in the snow with the pile facing down. Brush off the snow with a brush, and the rug is clean and fresh again.

359.title: Whiter Teeth
359.description: You can get whiter teeth at a low cost by brushing them with baking soda once a month. Be careful not to do this too often, as it can wear down enamel and gums!

360.title: Garlic Press
360.description: It's easier to remove garlic from a garlic press when you're done if you press the garlic with the tough skin still on!

361.title: Spring Planting
361.description: A good tip for spring planting is to start saving empty milk cartons early in winter. You can then cut the cartons and use the bottom part as a pot to start growing plants. Since they are square, they are easy to line up next to each other on a tray or table, and they are also easy to tear off when the plants are ready to be planted. It's also environmentally friendly because milk cartons are recycled, and economical because you don't have to buy plastic pots! An alternative to milk cartons can also be cut-up soda cans.

362.title: Fragrant Vacuum Cleaner
362.description: To avoid bad smells from the vacuum cleaner, you can suck in a cotton ball sprayed with a good perfume or cleaning agent, or a small pile of laundry detergent, into the vacuum cleaner.

363.title: Fragrant Car
363.description: If you don't want air fresheners hanging from the rearview mirror, you can instead place a cloth soaked in fabric softener under the seat. It spreads a mild, clean scent in the car.

364.title: Sharpening Eyeliner
364.description: An eyeliner pencil becomes easier to sharpen if you put the pencil in the freezer for a while before sharpening.

365.title: Eggshells in the Bowl
365.description: When cracking eggs into a bowl, it's easy for a piece of shell to go in. If you use the shell half to fish out the pieces, they won't slip away like they do when you try to grab them with your fingers.

366.title: Preventing Eggs from Cracking
366.description: If you add a teaspoon of silver to the boiling egg water, it attracts the bubbles, and the risk of the eggs cracking decreases.

367.title: Egg Whites
367.description: When whisking egg whites, it's easier, and the foam becomes firmer if you add a small pinch of salt.

368.title: Leftover Egg Whites
368.description: You can let this dry on a plate. When it has solidified, you can break it into pieces or turn it into powder. The homemade egg powder can then be whisked after being added to water, one leveled teaspoon is about the same as an egg white.

369.title: Highlighter Stains
369.description: Stains from most highlighters can be easily removed with vinegar spirit.

370.title: Stuck Lid
370.description: If it's hard to loosen a screw lid on a jar, you can insert the tip of a smaller knife between the jar and the lid from underneath and wiggle/screw a little on the knife until it clicks. Then it's easy to unscrew the lid.

371.title: Calcium on Shower Walls
371.description: Glass shower walls with lime deposits can be difficult to clean. Use a little window cleaner or cleaning spray directly on the glass and then rub everywhere with a crumpled parchment paper; it comes off easily. Just rinse with the shower afterward, and the walls are clean and shiny.

372.title: Homemade Drain Cleaner
372.description: When water drains slowly in the sink or basin, you can make your drain cleaner by pouring baking soda into the drain and then a little vinegar. Let it bubble for a while and then rinse with lukewarm water. Repeat as needed.

373.title: Shiny Sink and Basin
373.description: Cut a lemon in half and pour dish soap on the cut surface. Then rub the basin and sink with the lemon half with dish soap and rinse afterwards for a shiny sink.

374.title: Spilled Egg
374.description: If you spill raw egg, it can be difficult to clean up. Pour coarse salt over the egg before first possibly sweeping together and then wiping with a regular dishcloth so you get everything at once.

375.title: Paint Stains on Hands
375.description: If you've painted or crafted and got water-based paint on your hands, it can be difficult to remove everything with regular soap. Wash your hands in shaving foam instead, and most stains will come off in a snap.

376.title: Paint Stains on Hands 2
376.description: If you've painted with oil-based paints and have paint stains on your hands that are difficult to remove with just soap, take some rapeseed oil or similar cooking oil and use it as soap to dissolve the paint. Then wash your hands with dish soap to remove the oil. Afterwards, moisturize your hands as they can become dry from the dish soap.

377.title: Burnt Bottom of the Pot
377.description: If you have a pot that has become discolored on the bottom, it may be possible to remove it by cutting a potato in half and dipping the cut surface in regular table salt. Rinse the bottom of the pot and then rub with the potato until the brown disappears.

378.title: Dirty Iron
378.description: If you accidentally get burnt spots on the soleplate of the iron, you can remove them by pouring a little table salt on a parchment paper and then ironing the salt on medium heat with circular movements. This is when the burnt spots stick to the salt. If the iron is very dirty, you may need to repeat this with clean salt.

379.title: Dirty Silver Jewelry
379.description: Spray shaving foam in a bowl, place the jewelry in it, and cover it thoroughly with the foam. Scrub a little with a clean toothbrush and dry with a terrycloth towel for shiny clean silver jewelry.

380.title: Dull Cutlery
380.description: Put the cutlery in a container or similar, and cover it with hot water. Squeeze half a lemon into the water and let it sit for 10-15 minutes. Polish with a kitchen towel, and they will be shiny and nice again.

381.title: Dirty Shoe Soles
381.description: White shoe soles that have become dull can become white and nice again by taking a small bowl of table salt, squeezing a little lemon over it, and mixing it into a paste. Use a toothbrush to rub the mixture on the soles and then wipe clean.

382.title: Mobile/tablet Holder
382.description: If you quickly need a splash- and child-proof mobile holder for children in the back seat (or if several are watching the same movie), lift off the front seat headrest, place a large ziplock bag with the opening to the side so that the top edge is over the holes where the headrest should go back. Make a couple of small holes in the bag where the headrest pegs should go through and put the headrest back in place with the bag in between. Put on any movie, close the bag's zipper on the side, and enjoy a peaceful car ride.

383.title: Parchment Paper that Slides
383.description: When covering a baking pan with parchment paper, it is sometimes difficult to get it to stay in place. Pour a little water in the bottom of the pan before placing the paper, and then press it firmly into the bottom to keep it in place.

384.title: Parchment Paper that Slides 2
384.description: When covering a dish that is not suitable for parchment paper, it is sometimes difficult to get it to stay in place. Crumple the paper into a small ball. Then straighten out the parchment paper again and place it in the dish.

385.title: Vacuum Pack Food/Fruit
385.description: If you don't have a vacuum sealer in the kitchen, you can still vacuum pack non-liquid food (such as fruit pieces and the like) by placing them in a ziplock bag and inserting a straw into one side of the opening. Close up to the straw, suck out the air with the straw, and quickly pull the tube out of the bag while closing the last small part.

386.title: Too Little Wrapping Paper
386.description: Are you wrapping a gift and have too little wrapping paper for it to cover the entire present? Try placing the gift diagonally instead and wrap it, then the paper covers more of the surface.

387.title: Cooling Summer Snacks for Kids
387.description: On hot summer days or to relieve, for example, teething, you can make cooling snacks by squeezing small coins of fruit puree (homemade or from pouches) onto a tray and freezing for a while. Release with a spatula or cheese slicer, place in a bowl, and serve. Healthy and delicious!

388.title: Good Scent in the Bathroom
388.description: A clever air freshener for the bathroom can be made with the help of a sanitary pad and essential oil. Dab fragrant oil on the pad and then attach it with the adhesive on the underside somewhere it doesn't show, for example, behind the toilet or under the sink.

389.title: Too Small Shoes
389.description: New shoes that are a bit tight can be stretched by placing a ziplock bag in each shoe, filling the bag with water, closing it, and placing the shoes with the bags in the freezer. Water expands when it freezes and can help stretch out the shoes.

390.title: Perfect Folds on the Curtain
390.description: For even folds on a curtain with eyelets, you can place an empty toilet paper roll between every other eyelet (where the fabric hangs in front of the rod). This way, the curtain will have precise even folds.

391.title: Band-Aid That Fits
391.description: For a perfect fit on a band-aid around a finger, you can cut a slit from the middle of each short side (where the adhesive is) to the middle of the band-aid. Then place each "tab" so that the band-aid fits comfortably around the finger.

392.title: Sweaty Cap Lining
392.description: To keep the cap's lining fresh even during hot summer days or while exercising, you can attach a panty liner on the inside just above the brim.

393.title: Traveling with Jewelry
393.description: Chains and bracelets can easily tangle in the suitcase or toiletry bag. You can avoid this by cutting a straw to a suitable length, threading one end of the chain through the straw, and then fastening it on the outside.

394.title: Lighting Lanterns
394.description: If you need to light lanterns where it's hard to reach with a regular lighter and lack a long lighter, you can use uncooked spaghetti. Ignite the end of the spaghetti and use it to light the lanterns.

395.title: Dividing Cherry Tomatoes
395.description: If you need to divide many cherry tomatoes quickly, you can do it in one go by placing them between two lids (like those for food containers), holding the top lid, and cutting between the lids.

396.title: Awkward Cardboard for Recycling
396.description: After renovating or assembling furniture, the cardboard can be awkward to handle afterward. In the summertime, you can spray a little water on them with the hose, then they are easy to fold or roll up to transport away.

397.title: Scalp peeling
397.description: Combine roomtemperature coconutfat and granulated sugar. While showering massage it thorougly into the scalp for approximately five minutes. The peeling removes dead skincells and stimulates the blood circulation. Schampoo hair and scalp and make sure all residue from the peeling is washed away. Your scalp will fresh as ever. The peeling works great for the body too.

398.title: Fast pizzadough
398.description: If you want homemade pizza but doesn't have the time to wait for the dough to proof you can instead do the following: Take 140 gram all purpose flower, 0.5 ts salt and 0.75 ts baking poweder. Pour about 130 grams of natural yoghurt and 2 tbs of oil into the flour mixture and mix into a dough. if the dough feels to dry just add some yoghurt, if the dough feels to wet compensate with more flower. The dough should feel pliable. Let it rest for 10 minutes and then it's ready to be used.

399.title: Nickel allergy
399.description: If you have nice earrings you can't use because of allergy take a transparent nailpolish and apply it to the parts that have contact with the ear. When the nailpolish has dried you can use the earrings as usual.

400.title: Difficult trimming claws on rabbits and guineapigs
400.description: If it's difficult trimming the claws on your beloved pets you can create a rabbit/guineapig burrito. Place the animal on a bathtowel on the floor, bathtowel should be bigger widthwise than the animal. Wrap the animal into the towel as a burrito, take out one paw at a time and trim the claws.

401.title: Lemonjuice
401.description: Instead of slicing a whole lemon for a small amount of lemonjuice, you can create a small hole in the lemon and just squeeze out as much juice as needed.

402.title: Citrus juice and zest
402.description: To make sure you always have citrus juice at home you can squeeze the citrus fruits and poor it into ice cube trays and place in the freezer. Before cutting lemons to squeeze you can remove the zest, place in a container and freeze that too.

403.title: Non-stick grill grate
403.description: To prevent food from sticking to the grill grate when barbecuing, you can cut a potato in half and rub the cut side over the grate before starting to grill.

404.title: Mosquito-free
404.description: To deter mosquitoes and wasps from the patio, you can line a deep bowl or small dish with aluminium foil, then add coffee grounds and set them alight to create smoke. This works with both fresh coffee grounds and used coffee grounds.

405.title: Fresh clothes
405.description: Instead of taking your clothes to the dry cleaners, you can spray them with vodka. Spray especially where there is a lot of perspiration and allow them to air out, and your clothes will be fresh again.
